fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.bodyText: Landlords 'breaking the law' Many rules imposed by landlords break the 1999 Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Regulations, says the latest Which? Guide to Renting and Letting. Laws that were 'a minefield' have now produced an 'even more volatile situation', warns author Paul Betts. Potentially unlawful are bans on pets, subletting and overnight guests. The book costs £11.99. Isa gap exposed Returns on the best-paying mini cash Isas are 60 per cent higher than on those paying least, says researcher MoneyFacts. A National Counties Isa for customers with maturing Tessas was top in the financial year just ended, paying interest of £183.86 on a £3,000 deposit. The lowest payer among 124 accounts surveyed, the Cambridge building society, paid £110.86. The best return from a big bank was £157.73 from HSBC. The average return was £151.80. Good payers included Birmingham Midshires (£180), Leeds & Holbeck (£180), Portman (£179.51), Julian Hodge Bank (£177.97) and Staffordshire building society (£167.53). Rip-off hits home Homeowners over 50 often pay 'excessive home insurance premiums', says insurance broker Berry Birch & Noble. Its survey showed that 90 per cent could save by changing firms. The average annual premium they paid was £191.54, but the average revised quote from trawling the market was 22 per cent less, at £148.73. Debt beater A book for people with serious debts has been written by the chief executive of the Bankruptcy Association, John McQueen. It costs £9.95, p&p free, from the association on 01524 64305 or from 4 Johnson Close, Abraham Heights, Lancaster, LA1 5EU. The ethical way A new guide to ethical mortgages and insurance is available free from the Ethical Investment Research Service on 0845 606 0324. Called to account A new 166-page book explains accounting to the self-employed and small firms. 'If You're so Brilliant... How come you don't understand your accountant' is published by Kogan Page at £9.99 in bookshops, or on 01903 828800.
